After Mikhail Gorbachev came to office and introduced far-reaching reforms to the Soviet system in 1986, Reagan administration policy on nuclear arms began to change, and the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START) was eventually signed in 1991. The signing of the treaty, however, cannot be considered a positive example of government response to public preferences both because of the long delay and because of the apparently critical role of altered conditions in bringing about change in U.S. government policy
